headline: From Crew Member to Icon: Shania Twain Gets All Dressed Up with McDonald's Canada
summary: Get ready, Canada! McDonald's Canada and Shania Twain are turning up the flavour on two fan favourites, because you're never too dressed up to go to McDonald's and when you add a touch of style, even the best, feel-good moments get a delightful upgrade. For a limited time, McDonald's classics are getting all dressed up, Shania's way, with fan-favourite menu items and a keepsake that brings her flair.

headline: Big Blue Swim School Appoints Tracy Stockard as Chief Marketing Officer
summary: CHICAGO, August 11, 2025--Big Blue Swim School, one of the country's fastest-growing franchises in the $3 billion learn-to-swim industry, announces the appointment of Tracy Stockard as Chief Marketing Officer. A seasoned marketing executive with more than two decades of experience leading brand transformation for national and global consumer brands, Stockard will spearhead Big Blue’s marketing strategy as the brand enters its next chapter of growth.

headline: India calls for boycott of American goods over Trump tariffs
summary: STORY: From McDonald’s and Coca-Cola, to Apple and Amazon – giant U.S. brands are facing calls for a boycott in India. It’s a protest against Trump’s 50% tariffs on Indian goods…With business executives and Prime Minister Narendra Modi's supporters stoking anti-American sentiment.India’s a key growth market for American companies…With increasingly affluent consumers often associating international brands with moving up in life. The world’s most populous nation, for example, has more Domino’s restaurants than any other brand.Drinks like Pepsi and Coca-Cola often dominate store shelves, too. And people still queue up when an Apple store opens or a Starbucks cafe gives out discounts. Despite no immediate indication of sales being hit, there’s a growing narrative to buy local instead. It’s rattled exporters and damaged ties between New Delhi and Washington. And on Sunday, Modi made a “special appeal” for becoming self-reliant.McDonald's, Coca-Cola, Amazon and Apple did not immediately respond to Reuters queries.

raw.headline: India calls for boycott of American goods over Trump tariffs
raw.summary: STORY: From McDonald’s and Coca-Cola, to Apple and Amazon – giant U.S. brands are facing calls for a boycott in India. It’s a protest against Trump’s 50% tariffs on Indian goods…With business executives and Prime Minister Narendra Modi's supporters stoking anti-American sentiment.India’s a key growth market for American companies…With increasingly affluent consumers often associating international brands with moving up in life. The world’s most populous nation, for example, has more Domino’s restaurants than any other brand.Drinks like Pepsi and Coca-Cola often dominate store shelves, too. And people still queue up when an Apple store opens or a Starbucks cafe gives out discounts. Despite no immediate indication of sales being hit, there’s a growing narrative to buy local instead. It’s rattled exporters and damaged ties between New Delhi and Washington. And on Sunday, Modi made a “special appeal” for becoming self-reliant.McDonald's, Coca-Cola, Amazon and Apple did not immediately respond to Reuters queries.

headline: In India, Trump's tariffs spark calls to boycott American goods
summary: NEW DELHI (Reuters) -From McDonald's and Coca-Cola to Amazon and Apple, U.S.-based multinationals are facing calls for a boycott in India as business executives and Prime Minister Narendra Modi's supporters stoke anti-American sentiment to protest against U.S. tariffs.  India, the world's most populous nation, is a key market for American brands that have rapidly expanded to target a growing base of affluent consumers, many of whom remain infatuated with international labels seen as symbols of moving up in life.  India, for example, is the biggest market by users for Meta's WhatsApp and Domino's has more restaurants than any other brand in the country.

raw.headline: In India, Trump's tariffs spark calls to boycott American goods
raw.summary: NEW DELHI (Reuters) -From McDonald's and Coca-Cola to Amazon and Apple, U.S.-based multinationals are facing calls for a boycott in India as business executives and Prime Minister Narendra Modi's supporters stoke anti-American sentiment to protest against U.S. tariffs.  India, the world's most populous nation, is a key market for American brands that have rapidly expanded to target a growing base of affluent consumers, many of whom remain infatuated with international labels seen as symbols of moving up in life.  India, for example, is the biggest market by users for Meta's WhatsApp and Domino's has more restaurants than any other brand in the country.
